result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

Clerk: EZ. Defendant John J Norman III in court.  Attorney Christopher Hartley in court for John J Norman III.  Attorney Elizabeth A Longo in court for State of Wisconsin.  (21CF389 Br. 1; 22CF55 Br. 3)   Atty. Hartley is taking over on these cases and needs additional time to review all of the discovery but have a good understanding of the case and defendant has engaged in extensive AODA treatment and believe the cases will resolve and request adjournment to finalize plea negotiations.  State advises victim in 22CF71 is in court and objecting to a lengthy adjournment.  Victim makes statements and objects to another adjournment.  Court makes statements on victim's objection.  Court grants adjournment with anticipation that there will be progress on the adjourned date.
